body.p: “Close by the Great Aspen I saw where it had entered or come out of the water under a shelf of ice left adhering to a maple. There it apparently played and slid on the level ice “,” making a broad tail as if a shovel had been shoved along “,” just eight inches wide “,” without a foot-track in it for four feet or more. And again the trail was only two inches wide and between the foot-tracks “,” which were [image] side by side and twenty-two inches apart.”
PE 9, pg. 170 / 3 Sept 1854 – 12 May 1855 / NNPM MA 1302:24 / T vol. # XVIII / PDF # XIII
